Award.AwardTitle: IDBR - Development of an Ultrafast Phase-shaping Contrast Microscope
Award.AbstractNarration:
Project Abstract
The project will develop an Ultrafast Phase-Shaping Contrast Microscope (UPSCM) to provide enhanced imaging capabilities and new modes of imaging contrast for biological research. The UPSCM will exploit the amplitude and phase-shaping of a broadband laser in a versatile instrument that will have three modes of operation to meet a wide range of imaging needs. The first imaging modality will permit rapid and quantitative multiphoton fluorescence resonance energy transfer (MFRET) imaging. The proposed MFRET imaging modality is orders of magnitude faster than current technology, opening up new opportunities for studying protein-protein interactions in animal and tissue models and will be readily extended to video-rate imaging speeds. The second imaging modality of the UPSCM will be two-color pump-probe contrast microscopy. This modality will exploit pump-probe contrast mechanisms including stimulated emission, excited state absorption and ground-state bleach to enable sensitive imaging of nonfluorescent and weakly fluorescent endogenous species. Finally, the third imaging modality will employ a single shaped laser pulse designed to provide molecular contrast as well as insight into the energy landscape of the molecule.
Multiphoton microscopy has revolutionized our ability to visualize the biological world. Multiphoton excitation markedly enhances the depth of imaging into tissues, and provides novel modes of contrast. Multiphoton fluorescence microscopy has been widely used and has been shown to increase signal-to-background for fluorescence while reducing photodamage and photobleaching, permitting more sensitive detection of fluorescence signals over extended periods of time. However, in a typical multiphoton fluorescence microscope, a tunable femtosecond laser is used to image a single fluorescent probe, making the simultaneous observation of multiple chemical species difficult. The proposed UPSCM will employ an extremely broadband femtosecond laser to allow selective and simultaneous multiphoton fluorescence imaging of commonly used fluorescent probes. This methodology will facilitate studies of protein-protein interactions in transgenic animals, enabling new studies of cellular signaling in healthy and diseased animals. In addition to enhanced multiphoton fluorescence imaging, the UPSCM will provide novel, sensitive and selective contrast for nonfluorescent endogenous species that will be broadly applicable to imaging studies aimed at improving current understanding of basic cellular processes and methods for disease diagnosis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported the development of an Ultrafast Phase-Shaping Contrast Microscope (UPSCM) to provide enhanced imaging capabilities for biological research. The unique design of this microscope employs a single broadband laser, tailoring the characteristics of the broadband laser pulses to enable new modes of imaging contrast with a single instrument. The new imaging modalities demonstrated with the UPSCM were: rapid and quantitative multiphoton fluorescence resonance energy transfer (MFRET) imaging and two-color pump-probe contrast microscopy (2CPPM).

 The major motivation for developing MFRET was to enable quantitative measurements of protein-protein interactions in tissues and for in vivo studies. One photon FRET microscopy has found wide applications in biophysical, chemical and biomedical research. However, it has limited depth penetration, making it unsuitable for deep tissue and in vivo applications. Multiphoton FRET offers the advantages of greatly improved depth penetration, automatic three dimensional imaging, and reduced problems of fluorophore photobleaching. Powerful one photon FRET stoichiometry methods have previously been developed to enable quantitative measurements of protein-protein interactions. However, these methods have been difficult to extend to MFRET while maintaining rapid imaging capabilities. Using a broadband laser in combination with pulse-shaping, we have demonstrated MFRET stoichiometry. Our approach exploits the ability of the pulse-shaped excitation from a broadband laser to specifically target fluorophores of interest and disentangle their fluorescence signals, enabling quantitative measurements of protein-protein interactions. The development of MFRET stoichiometry required adapting the one photon stoichiometry theory to account for differences between one photon and multiphoton excitation. MFRET stoichiometry will provide a powerful tool for in vivo studies of signaling pathways in healthy and diseased organisms.

We have also demonstrated two-color pump-probe contrast microscopy (2CPPM). This microscope modality enables imaging of endogenous pigments that do not fluoresce. As a model system for label-free imaging we chose hemoglobin in red blood cells. We demonstrated the ability to successfully image red blood cells using 2CPPM. The ability to image heme proteins has numerous applications for biophysical and biomedical imaging, enabling the visualization of vascular networks and their metabolic activity. The method can also be applied to image other endogenous pigments such as melanin, and may find applications in studies of pigmentation disorders and skin cancer. The approach could also find applications in other fields such as material and energy sciences.

The broader impacts of the work include the extensive training of two undergraduate and graduate students and one postdoctoral fellow in experimental and optical design and construction, data analysis and scientific communication. This grant has supported outreach efforts by the PI to share the excitement of scientific discovery with the general public through public lectures and lab tours to economically disadvantaged high school students and Girl scout troops. To encourage young women to pursue careers in Physics, the PI worked with the Society of Women in Physics to host an APS Conference for Undergraduate Women in Physics at the University of Michigan in January 2015. The conference brought together 130 undergraduate women from across the country to network and explore career opportunities for physicists through lab tours, research presentations, career and discussion panels and skills-building workshops.
